Message.Title: Google Surrenders. Withdraws entire ITC complaint against Apple.
Message.Msg: "Apple does what Apple does and Nobody else is going to compete with them." -- Jen Hsun Huang, MobileBeat, March 4, 2011. Google/Motorola finally came to their senses, boys. And realized that Nobody is going to compete with Apple in a Court of Law. Nobody. And accordingly, just two (2) weeks into the estimated sixteen (16) Month legal battle, Google/Motorola WITHDREW THEIR ENTIRE ITC COMPLAINT against Apple. Which had accused Apple of infringing on seven non-standard-essential patents. It's a classic, Total and Absolute Surrender by Google/Motorola, boys. Following Apple's thermonuclear attack on Google. Well, except for the Navy battleship and signing ceremony and flags and this and that. Google's sudden surrender to Apple has left many, well, searching for words. Which can be found here: Google's Motorola Mobility withdraws its entire second ITC complaint against Apple Foss

Topic.Title: Breaking news. Amazon orders 10,000 Tesla k10

Message.Msg: "Amazon's tough negotiating stance did drive the price down. While we expected that the boards would be discounted down from $4,999 from $2,499 to $2,999 range, truth was a little bit different. Amazon allegedly paid as low as $1,499 to $1,799 per card, bringing a value of the order between 15 and 18 million U.S. dollars. Tesla comes with an interesting subscription warranty program, which sets the customer back for additional $500 per board per year. That money guarantees immediate replacement should the board fail. Our sources implied that the company took that option in a heartbeat [Amazon had probably heard about nvidia's reputation for shoddy goods] , expecting to pay around $1000 to $1,500 per board (2-3y lifespan). All in all, with this one deal, Nvidia should net between 25 and 28 million U.S. dollars from a single customer. Naturally, the success of GK104 die in the HPC space and the limited supply from TSMC have another consequence - potential shortage in the consumer segment." So nvidia sold out cheap to Amazon -- like Really Dirt Cheap -- and threw the high margin consumer gamers under the bus, since the razor-thin Amazon order will cause "limited supply and potential shortage" for the high profit consumer segment. And this is somehow a good deal for nvda shareholders? Hummm? Looks like Desperation by Jen to get some hollow revenues NOW to show The Street.

Topic.Title: Breaking news. Amazon orders 10,000 Tesla k10

Message.Msg: With the subscription fee, the article that you both cite says the deal should still end up being $25-28M in revenue from Amazon on this order alone, even after accounting for the supposed discount priced -- the key being the subscription revenue that you mention critically but don't include in your revenue number. The more important thing, though, is that it sets two important an important precedent that could/should have two key consequences: 1) Amazon making large unit orders for Tesla products... as suggested in the article you both site, it seems likely that Amazon will also being purchasing K20s, and those should be closer to MSRP given supply constraints (aka, the Kepler GPUs are still being sold as quickly as they can possibly be produced) 2) Other companies building AWS competitors that want to compete in high performance computing will also consider Tesla... getting the "design win" in AWS HPC is tantamount to a massive reference design win for the performance computing market. Last quarter, the company reported 15% sequential top line growth in GPU, 35% growth in Consumer Products (Tegra + Icera), and a single digit decline in their Professional Solutions segment. Seems as though we can now expect to see Q3 showing sequential growth in Professional Solutions (as management suggested on the Q2 call). Remember, the midpoint of their raised guidance is $1.2B -- lots of ways getting there, but if they post another 15% Q/Q growth for GPU (thanks to increased supply) and 35% growth in Consumer products (an acceleration from Q2, based on a full quarter of providing Tegra for nexus 7 and the pre-launch ramp of the Surface RT, among others) -- that'd imply expectations of Professional Solutions to show 6% sequential growth. Or maybe the counter argument by "best" et al is that the GPU and/or Consumer Product businesses are actually going to show even stronger sequential growth (which seems to be at conflict with the bear case).

Message.Title: Texas Instruments OMAP 5 slips to 2013
Message.Msg: Could not make it in 2012 Despite the rumors started by Reuters who stated that Texas instrument is giving up on the mobile market and halts the OMAP 5 development, TI is continuing to fight in this market, at least for another year. TI has a quite long gap between OMAP 4 and OMAP 5 but it is expected to see the OMAP 5 early next year. The company thinks that slight speed bump of OMAP 4 parts that launched at 1.0GHz to 1.2GHz with very successful OMAP 4430 in Q1 2011 the got to 1.2 to 1.5GHz in Q4 2011 with OMAP 4460 can reach over 1.5GHz with OMAP 4470 that gets to launch with Archos tablets, Nook HD and Kindle Fire HD 8.9. Mass availability of OMAP 4470 is expected in Q4 2012, the quarter we live since this is the timeframe when we expect the increased production of tablets based on OMAP 4 especially the new Kindle and Nook flavors. Some people are even claiming that OMAP5 might be the first Cortex A15 chip to market, but somehow we think that Nvidia might beat them to it. We have a funny feeling that we might see both chips at CES and at the latest in early February 2013 at Barcelona based Mobile World Congress. Despite the small delay TI and OMAP 5 still coming to market and we would be very surprised if we don’t see at least some major design wins. Texas Instruments is doing fine with design wins of the Barnes & Noble and for two consecutive years with Amazon Kindle tablets too, and we see that this partnership is here to stay, unless challenged by some offer from the competition that Amazon or Barnes & Noble could not resist. It is quite certain that we will see at least a few OMAP 5 design wins in 2013, but we also reportedly heard that Texas Instruments will be late to market with its OMAP 4 and OMAP 5 based Windows 8 tablets and notebooks, mainly due to driver related issues. There is no doubt that Qualcomm and Nvidia will fight for the crown in ARM market but let’s also don’t forget that two big ones Samsung and Apple make their own chip leaving a very tight space for fearsome competition. It remains to be seen if Texas Instruments continues to develop high performance mobile chips after OMAP 5 and has good parts for a competition with many quad and octa cores in 2013 and beyond.

Topic.Title: Texas Instruments OMAP 5 slips to 2013

Message.Msg: I think TXN has fallen on the list of competitors for Nvidia, and the top 3 in the SoC space (outside of Apple and Samsung) are Qualcomm, Mediatek, and Intel. If Nvidia fails to gain/maintain significant share (I think Jen-Hsun Huang has state on CCs that they need it to get to $1B+ a year to be sustainable) then I think they can have a successful business licensing their GPU IP to the other SoC makers... this could even re-open the doors at Samsung and Apple. Intel is paying $1.5B Nvidia over six years based on their 2011 settlement ($900M in 4 annual payments still owed). A few licensing deals near that scale could add up very quickly. This of course is a back-up plan. Plan A is leveraging their strength in graphics to become a dominant SoC provider to all non-Samsung/non-Apple devices, from smartphones and tablets (Tegra) through notebooks/pcs (Denver) and up through supercomputers (Boulder).

Topic.Title: Google Surrenders. Withdraws entire ITC complaint against Apple.

Message.Msg: iDiot, Google intends to checkmate Apple in 2013 with such a move! ================== The complaint can be re-submitted. Florian Mueller, who was first to report the withdrawal on his blog, said he believed that Google withdrew the complaint to prevent it from being consolidated with an earlier case, thus slowing that case down. In that case, an ITC judge had said in a preliminary ruling that Apple infringed on a patent for eliminating noise and other interference during voice and data transmissions. A final decision is due next April. ==================

Topic.Title: Breaking news. Amazon orders 10,000 Tesla k10

Message.Msg: The gross profit margin for NVIDIA CORP is rather high; currently it is at 51.80%. It has increased from the same quarter the previous year. Regardless of the strong results of the gross profit margin, the net profit margin of 11.40% trails the industry average. NVDA's revenue growth trails the industry average of 13.9%. Since the same quarter one year prior, revenues slightly increased by 2.7%. This growth in revenue does not appear to have trickled down to the company's bottom line, displayed by a decline in earnings per share.

Message.Title: Is this the Problem?
Message.Msg: Jen-Hsun Huang Co-founder, President and Chief Executive Officer Jen-Hsun Huang co-founded NVIDIA Corporation in April 1993 and has served as President, Chief Executive Officer, and a member of the Board of Directors since its inception. Under his leadership, NVIDIA has become the world leader in programmable graphics processing technologies and one of the semiconductor industry’s largest fabless companies. Mr. Huang serves on the RAND Corporation’s Board of Trustees and is a member of the Committee of 100, an organization that addresses issues concerning the Chinese-American community and U.S.-China relations. In 2004, the Fabless Semiconductor Association honored Mr. Huang with the prestigious Dr. Morris Chang Exemplary Leadership Award, which recognizes a leader who has made exceptional contributions to driving the development, innovation, growth, and long-term opportunities of the fabless semiconductor industry. Additionally, Mr. Huang is a recipient of the Daniel J. Epstein Engineering Management Award from the University of Southern California and was named an Alumni Fellow by Oregon State University. Prior to founding NVIDIA, Mr. Huang held engineering, marketing, and general management positions at LSI Logic, and was a microprocessor designer at Advanced Micro Devices. Mr. Huang holds a #$%$.E.E. degree from Oregon State University and an M.S.E.E. degree from Stanford University. No business degree. Business experience? Running NVDA? Result=bad job, need a new CEO/COB!

Topic.Title: Breaking news: AT&T announces the availability of ASUS vivoTab RT tablet with Tegra 3/LTE for the holiday season

Message.Msg: So what's this misleading, newly invented nomenclature all about, boys? Specificially, that "Tegra® 3 TE" jive. The speed reader -- or the not-so-closely-paying-attention reader -- might be bamboozled -- yes, bamboozled boys -- by the cunningly deceptive nvidia PR Department into Thinking that the Tegra® 3 now has an integrated on-board LTE radio. Like Qualcomm's ever-growing Family of Snapdragons with integrated on-board LTE radios. Except the Tegra ® 3 doesn't. Nope. The deceptively named Tegra® 3 TE has NO integrated LTE radio. Or ANY integrated radio at All, for that matter. Maybe the cunningly deceptive nvidia PR Department deliberately Schemed to come up with a name that would Convey the Impression that nvidia/icera have finally figured out how to put both a tegra AND the on-board LTE radio side-by-side on the same little piece of silicon. Hummm? When in Fact, those than read best clearly know that nvidia/icera is still Nowhere Close to having an integrated LTE radio. Like Qualcomm's ever-growing Family of Snapdragons with integrated on-board LTE radios. So what's next from the nvidia Misleading Nomenclature Department? "The NVIDIA next-generation quad-core Tegra® 3 x68."

Message.Msg: So Best? What you're saying is, that nvidia is just like a wet cat. Yes, a wet cat, boys. And that under all that hyped up hair is just another rat. Yes boys, a cunningly deceptive rat.
